author: sky.cactus
content: Excess gas is not used.  The system just needs to make sure you *can* afford to pay for whatever gas limit you set.

author: sky.cactus
content: In the end you only pay for what you use, unless you `assert` or do something that causes an invalid failure.

author: pragmatic_landshark
content: I had a thought while listening to the ACD Post London Breakout #12 discussion about the challenge of predicting future demand for gas....  Many of the spikes in gas fees can be attributed to things like NFT launches, liquidations, or new features that are behind time-locks with a known target block #.  Has anyone thought about the possibility of allowing users to submit transactions for future inclusion (i.e. notBeforeBlock 1234567).  This would give rise to a market similar to AWS EC2 Reserved Instances where tx's submitted early may be eligible for a baseFee discount as an incentive for broadcasting their intent early.

author: Deleted User
content: do you really want to add more complexity after the fiasco that is eip1559? i know that some considers it a success because it is burning fees but from a usability standpoint + more it seems worse. and you want to add more complexity it seems. when does it stop.

author: .vbuterin
content:
> Has anyone thought about the possibility of allowing users to submit transactions for future inclusion (i.e. notBeforeBlock 1234567).

Account abstraction may end up being a good opportunity to start doing this sort of stuff

author: Deleted User
content: maybe it is too soon to judge eip1559

author: Deleted User
content: according to ethereum website if you set price limit lower the required you gas is consumed <@!301186049323958275>

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, but DoS vectors can be a problem.  "Not before" is easier than "not after" though from a DoS standpoint.

author: sky.cactus
content: Do you mean gas limit?  If so, you have to set it equal to or higher than what you need.  Otherwise your transaction will fail.

author: gwintery
content:
Not sure where the 'fiasco' you're talking about here? Unless you're of course being hyperbolic.

Gas fees are roughly where they are before 1559 launched. We see the algorithm handling spikes due to NFT spikes quite well. Miner tips rarely exceed the block reward now which is one of the concerns eip 1559 is trying to solve. 

I have had an easy time to put my transactions included within a few blocks just by eyeballing the basefee so far. Hoping the tooling improves within the next few weeks.

Overall I would say it went OK ish. Unless of course the fiasco is that miner rewards are decreased. (Which seems to be where most of the people who says its a complete failure come from).

author: Deleted User
content: Im asking why they consume the gas

author: Deleted User
content: why dont I get it back ?

author: Deleted User
content: in bitcoin it gives you the amount back if the transaction failed because of priority

author: sky.cactus
content: Because you are still costing the network resources even if your transaction fails.

author: sky.cactus
content: In Bitcoin, transactions can't really fail.  They are either valid (includable) or not valid (not includable).

author: sky.cactus
content: In Ethereum, there are transactions that are valid (includable) but fail during execution.

author: Deleted User
content: what makes them fail ? lower gas limit only ? or there is other reasons?

author: Deleted User
content: if I pay only base fee x gas limit without priority will the eth consume?

author: sky.cactus
content: Depends on what you are trying to do.  For a simple ETH transfer, those usually don't fail unless you are sending to a contract that doesn't accept ETH.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are calling some complex contract, then there are many possible reasons why the transaction would fail.
